bibl.title: Letter from Theodore M. Purdy to Philip Showalter Hench, January 20, 1948

div1.p: Purdy's publishing house, Appleton-Century, is interested in Hench's planned book on Walter Reed and yellow fever.

div1.head: Letter from Theodore M. Purdy to Philip Showalter Hench, January 20, 1948
div1.opener:
D. APPLETON-CENTURY COMPANY
(INCORPORATED)
35 WEST 32ND STREET
NEW YORK 1. N. Y.
January 20, 1948
AC
Dr. Philip S. Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minnesota
Dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
Mr. McDermott of our Medical Department told
me recently that you have been working on a popular
book on the fascinating subject of Walter Reed and his
yellow fever discoveries. What he tells me of this
book and of your other work makes me feel that it
might be a distinct possibility for our trade list. I
am anxious to know whether we may not have the pleasure
of considering it for early publication.

I realize that you may not wish to submit
anything before the book is finished, but this letter
is merely to assure you that in any case we would be
delighted to learn any details from you, and to
consider the manuscript or any part of it whenever
you care to send it to us. I can promise that it will
have our very best attention.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours Theodore M. Purdy
Editor, Trade Books TMP:lem
